subject: Re: [junit] your opinion needed: package for unit testing codes
msgSnippet: Thanks for sharing this. I like this even better. Sorry if I led us down a rathole off the main JUnit subject, but I thought perhaps the project organization
messageBody:
Thanks for sharing this. I like this even better.

Sorry if I led us down a rathole off the main JUnit subject, but I
thought perhaps the project organization is
a part of using JUnit successfully.

Charles

Vladimir Ritz Bossicard wrote:

> Quoting Charles Hayes <charles.hayes@...>:
>
> > This is basically the same structure I use. I'm following the exact
> same
> > structure recommended in the book called "Java Development with Ant".
> >
> > So I have something like:
> >
> > projects
> > +- src
> > +- build
> > +- test
> > | +- src
> > | +- classes
> > | +- data (xml files)
> > | +- reports (test results in API style)
> > +- javadoc
> >
> > I hope my little textual diagram doesn't get too screwed up on your
> > email clients.
>
> And (yet) another alternative:
>
> projects
> build.xml
> +- src
> | +- java
> | +- config
> +- test
> | +- java
> | +- config
> | +- data
> +- build
> | +- classes
> | +- classes-test
> | +- javadoc
> | +- reports
>
> The goal is to separate the source files from the produced files:
>
> - impossible to commit produced files into cvs (just add 'build' in your
> .cvsignore)
> - 'rm -rf build' and you have a clean environment
>
> But that's just me
>
> -Vladimir
>
> --
> Vladimir Ritz Bossicard
> www.bossicard.com
>
